abstract: Rachel L Swarns The Working Life column observes that hundreds of unpaid creditors are preparing to fight in bankruptcy court over remains of FEGS Health and Human Services, including former chief executive Gail Magaliff, who is claiming $1.2 million in deferred compensation; notes that Magaliff's claim has led to outrage among many who see her as major contributor to downfall of what was one of New York City's largest social service agencies.

abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column notes that birthrate in New York City has been on steady decline, hitting lowest level since Great Depression, but not in wealthy neighborhoods; observes TriBeCa logged one of highest birthrates in city in 2013; suggests drop among working- and middle-class families in city may be due to cost of child-rearing in age of such heightened expectations, particularly for education.

abstract: Series of studies published in journal Environmental Health Perspectives raises urgent concerns about new generation of poly- and perfluoroalkyl substances, chemicals that are used in thousands of common consumer products; previous generations of PFAs were shown to increase risk of cancer; scientists, including Linda S Birnbaum of the Health and Human Services Dept, say new crop has been insufficiently studied and may carry similar risks.

abstract: Sudden death of Air Force recruit T J Moore during basic training illustrates major health care disadvantages faced by American service members; independent examination of Moore's records indicates serious lapses by military doctors, but Air Force has yet to admit any error; rules bar service members from seeking outside medical attention, and deprive them of right to challenge their care and seek answers by filing malpractice suits (Series: Military Medicine).

abstract: Residents of West Baltimore's poverty-stricken Upton-Druid Heights neighborhood, which is 94 percent black, die from almost every major disease at significantly higher rates than rest of city and their life expectancy is just 68 years; statistics underlie anger and frustration of poor black Americans that is at heart of ongoing nationwide protests about policing.

abstract: Britain's National Health Service, universal health system that has achieved revered status in country since its creation in 1948, has emerged as central factor in coming national elections; both Conservative and Labour party have presented themselves as protectors of system, pledging to allocate large new sums to shore up its strained resources.

headline: Global Cancer Drug Spending Hits $100 Billion in 2014-IMS Health
paragraph: Worldwide spending on cancer medicines reached $100 billion (66 billion pounds) in 2014, an increase of 10.3 percent from 2013 and up from $75 billion five years earlier, according to IMS Health's Global Oncology Trend Report released on Tuesday.

headline: GOP Plans for Reacting to Supreme Court Ruling on Health Law
paragraph: Congressional Republicans have yet to unite behind any of the growing number of proposals for responding to a Supreme Court ruling that could void federal subsidies that millions of people use to buy coverage under President Barack Obama's health care law. The decision is expected by June.

headline: Officer in Fatal Arrest Once Hospitalized Over Mental Health

abstract: Clearer picture emerges of Felix David, Manhattan man who was fatally shot as police attempted to arrest him on suspicion of robbery; David was itinerant man with long history of mental illness, including paranoid schizophrenia; detective Harold Carter, who shot David, had been made aware of his condition prior to incident.

abstract: Government officials release most detailed report to date on Medicare spending, revealing intricate picture of 36 million patients and $103 billion in total expenditures; heartburn medication Nexium, which accounted for largest spending on single drug, was prescribed to 1.5 million patients at total cost of $2.5 billion; officials express hope that deluge of information will yield useful analysis as experts weigh in.

abstract: Sandeep Jauhar The End column speaks of dilemma that doctors face in so-called futile cases, or patients with a grim prognosis; holds that while obliged to do no harm, many feel crisis of conscience when asked by family members to extend treatment to prolong life when risks exceed benefit; welcomes advances toward establishment of uniform standards to govern futile care.

abstract: Estimated 5,000 independent natural products retailers are headed by former activists and health food pioneers now reaching retirement age and facing decision on whether to close, sell to strangers, or turn business over to their children; familial business transitions can be difficult and complicated, and experts say taking the time to get outside advice in planning the turnover can be critical to to ensuring stable second-generation ownership.
headline: Health Food Retailers Make Way for the Next Generation
paragraph: Those who started health food and natural product stores in the 1970s and ’80s often face the transition problems found in many family businesses.

abstract: Paula Span The New Old Age column examines fallacy of notion that safest place for elderly patients is a hospital; contends that skilled nursing facilities can be a better and safer alternative, but notes that many nursing homes lack enough nurses qualified for some common procedures done in hospitals.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPANIER, MAURY
paragraph:
SPANIER--Maury L.

The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of our former Trustee Maury L. Spanier. For more than 40 years, Maury served our hospitals with enthusiasm and distinction, first as a Trustee and Member of the Executive Committee of the former Beth Israel Medical Center and then as a Trustee of Continuum Health Partners. Maury will long be remembered for his vision and wise counsel, and we extend our deepest condolences to his sons, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Steven Hochberg, Senior Vice Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO; Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, MAURICE
paragraph:
COHN--Maurice J. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn the loss of Life Trustee Maurice J. (Sonny) Cohn, a long-time benefactor of North Shore-LIJ and North Shore University Hospital (NSUH). Sonny and his wife Marilyn were committed to ensuring that the best emergency care was available to the community. Thanks to their generosity, the Marilyn and Maurice Cohn Trauma Center at NSUH provides the highest level of quality care to patients. Sonny's friendship, philanthropic support and dedication to the health system helped North Shore-LIJ become a regional and national leader in healthcare. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Marilyn, daughters Karen Cohn and Marcia Cohn, brother Milton (Bud), grandchildren Sarah, Hannah, and Aaron Rosenbaum, and the rest of the family. The funeral will be at 1pm on Thursday, May 7, 2015, at Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Shiva will be observed at the Cohn's home, 54 Elderfields Road, Manhasset, NY, on Friday, May 8, from 1-6pm and Sunday, May 10, from 1-6pm.

Mark L. Claster, Chairman, Board of Trustees, North Shore-LIJ Health System Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, North Shore-LIJ Health System

headline: Guinea: 11 Accused in Ebola Worker Deaths Get Life Sentences
paragraph: A Guinea court sentenced 11 people accused of killing eight Ebola health workers and journalists last year to life in prison on Tuesday.
text: Guinea: 11 Accused in Ebola Worker Deaths Get Life Sentences A Guinea court sentenced 11 people accused of killing eight Ebola health workers and journalists last year to life in prison on Tuesday.

headline: Human or robot - you decide
paragraph: An ultra-realistic humanoid robot called 'Han' recognises and interprets people's facial expressions and can even hold simple conversations. Developers Hanson Robotics hope androids like Han could have uses in hospitality and health care industries where face-to-face communication is vital. Matthew Stock reports.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, JOHN S.T
paragraph: GALLAGHER--John S.T. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn the loss of John "Jack" S.T. Gallagher, the health system's founding president and chief executive officer. Jack died suddenly Saturday night, April 18, of a heart attack at his home in Palm Beach, FL. He was 83. Jack was a legendary leader whose foresight and vision as president and CEO of North Shore University Hospital (NSUH) in Manhasset laid the groundwork in the early 1990s for hospital mergers on Long Island and Queens, creating a model for the integrated health systems that are so prevalent in today's healthcare market. During an era when managed care was first taking hold and hospitals were struggling financially, Jack sought to level the playing field for healthcare providers. He negotiated a merger with what was then known as Community Hospital at Glen Cove in 1990, before formally establishing the North Shore Health System in 1992. Over the next four years, he would develop relationships with Huntington, Plainview, Franklin, Forest Hills, Syosset, Staten Island University and Southside hospitals, before the network expanded further with the 1997 merger with Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Medical Center. The historic merger created the North Shore-LIJ Health System that stands today as the largest in New York State and the nation's 11th largest non-profit health system. A Queens native who obtained a business degree from Holy Cross College, Jack left the family tire business in his early 30s to begin pursuing a career in healthcare administration, earning a master of science degree from Yale University in epidemiology and public health. He joined the administrative staff at what was then called North Shore Hospital as an intern in 1963, working for then-Executive Vice President and CEO Dennis Buckley. The two would work closely together over the next two decades before Jack became president and CEO in the 1980s - a job he would hold until his retirement at the end of 2000. He had continued to serve as a life trustee of the health system. In addition to his unparalleled dedication and commitment to his work, Jack was extremely affable and approachable, enjoying coffee and breakfast with front-line staff and playing the piano at hospital holiday parties and other gatherings. On behalf of the staff and trustees of the entire North Shore-LIJ Health System, we extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Aileen O'Halloran Gallagher; sons John, Robert, Thomas and Paul; daughters Grace Haggerty and Louise Grecco; seven step-children; 27 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. In honor of Jack, flags at all North Shore-LIJ facilities will be flown at half-staff. Calling hours will be held this Thursday, April 23, from 3pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm at the Oyster Bay Funeral Home. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday, April 24, at 10am at St. Gertrude's Catholic Church in Bayville. Please join us in remembering Jack and his family in your thoughts and prayers. Mark L. Claster, Chairman, Board of Trustees, North Shore-LIJ Health System Michael J. Dowling, President & CEO, North Shore-LIJ Health System 1/3

headline: Indiana HIV Outbreak, Hepatitis C Epidemic Sparks CDC Alert
paragraph: An Indiana county is experiencing nearly daily increases in new HIV infections tied to intravenous drug use, and health officials hope the situation prompts other states to closely track their hepatitis C and HIV rates to identify potential clusters of the diseases.
text: Indiana HIV Outbreak, Hepatitis C Epidemic Sparks CDC Alert An Indiana county is experiencing nearly daily increases in new HIV infections tied to intravenous drug use, and health officials hope the situation prompts other states to closely track their hepatitis C and HIV rates to identify potential clusters of the diseases.

headline: Indiana Governor Extends Needle-Exchange Program to Curb HIV
paragraph: Indiana Gov. Mike Pence on Monday extended a needle exchange program in a rural, southern Indiana county to help combat an HIV outbreak, even though he generally opposes such programs.
text: Indiana Governor Extends Needle-Exchange Program to Curb HIV Indiana Gov. Mike Pence on Monday extended a needle exchange program in a rural, southern Indiana county to help combat an HIV outbreak, even though he generally opposes such programs.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAURER, PHOEBE
paragraph:
MAURER--Phoebe.

The RiverSpring Health and Hebrew Home at Riverdale families mourn the passing of Phoebe Maurer, a passionate and talented artist and author, who was deeply devoted to her husband Herb of 70 years, and her children, Ira, Gale and Jeffrey, the Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Hebrew Home at Riverdale. Phoebe's spirit, pride and wit will live on in the hearts of all who knew her. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Maurer and Finger families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Daniel Reingold President and CEO RiverSpring Health

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, JOHN SILAS T
paragraph: GALLAGHER--John Silas T. December 9, 1931 - April 18, 2015. We are deeply saddened to announce that John S.T. Gallagher passed away peacefully at his home in Palm Beach on Saturday, April 18. He was born on December 9, 1931, in Jackson Heights, New York of Mercedes Wright Gallagher and Thomas Gallagher, Sr. He attended Xavier High School and graduated with a BS in Business Administration from Holy Cross College and a Masters of Science, Epidemiology and Public Health from Yale University. As a great visionary with a caring heart, he embarked on his career in the health care industry and, as he would say, "gave birth" to the North Shore Health System. Ultimately, as Chief Executive of the North Shore-LIJ Health System, John Gallagher did more than any single individual to mold the Long Island hospital market, as referenced in the Newsday article "100 Who Shaped a Century". After changing careers in his 30s, leaving the family tire business to study public health at Yale University, the Queens native had been driven by a vision of a superior health care system that would not only survive the assault of profit-driven managed care companies but thrive and deliver charity care to the poor as well. Gallagher, a workaholic with an affable nature, joined the administrative staff at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset in 1963 as an intern. He was appointed Executive Vice President in 1982. In the 1990s, when managed care started making inroads into New York, Gallagher began hatching a plan to develop an integrated health care system, joining multiple hospitals and care facilities that could span a broad geographic area, achieve economies of scale and, most important, be able to exercise muscle in rate negotiations with insurance companies and HMOs. More recently, he merged the North Shore Health System with the Long Island Jewish Medical Center to create the North Shore-LIJ Health System, a powerhouse of 18 hospitals and numerous outpatient centers that stretches from Suffolk to Staten Island. It is no exaggeration to say that Jack Gallagher's vision is one of the reasons that the North Shore-LIJ Health System exists today. After his retirement, he remained active, serving on many boards. When Jack was not playing the piano or painting, he would be on the water enjoying his boat. He is survived by his wife, Aileen O'Halloran Gallagher, six children: John, Grace, Robert, Louise, Thomas and Paul, seven stepchildren, 27 grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. For his friendship, for his wisdom, for his deep sense of caring, he will be missed. Visitation will be at Oyster Bay Funeral Home on Thursday, April 23 from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Gertrude RC Church in Bayville, NY on Friday, April 24 at 10am. Interment is private. oysterbayfuneralhome.com 1/3

headline: Pence Signs Needle-Exchange Bill as HIV Outbreak Cases Grow
paragraph: Indiana communities facing an HIV epidemic tied to intravenous drug use will have a way to implement needle-exchange programs under a measure Gov. Mike Pence signed into law Tuesday, as the number of confirmed cases in a rural outbreak grew to nearly 150.
text: Pence Signs Needle-Exchange Bill as HIV Outbreak Cases Grow Indiana communities facing an HIV epidemic tied to intravenous drug use will have a way to implement needle-exchange programs under a measure Gov. Mike Pence signed into law Tuesday, as the number of confirmed cases in a rural outbreak grew to nearly 150.

headline: One Dead, 23 Others Sick From Suspected Botulism at Ohio Church
paragraph: A woman has died and 23 others were sickened by a suspected botulism outbreak after a potluck lunch at an Ohio church, health officials said on Wednesday.
text: One Dead, 23 Others Sick From Suspected Botulism at Ohio Church A woman has died and 23 others were sickened by a suspected botulism outbreak after a potluck lunch at an Ohio church, health officials said on Wednesday.

headline: 1 Dead, 18 Ill With Botulism Symptoms After Church Picnic
paragraph: One person died and at least 18 others were sickened with suspected food-borne botulism after attending a church picnic in central Ohio, a hospital said Tuesday.
text: 1 Dead, 18 Ill With Botulism Symptoms After Church Picnic One person died and at least 18 others were sickened with suspected food-borne botulism after attending a church picnic in central Ohio, a hospital said Tuesday.

headline: Judge Halts Worker's Comp Claim for Ebola Nurse Nina Pham
paragraph: A Texas district judge on Monday put on hold a hospital operator's efforts to seek a worker's compensation claim for a nurse who contracted Ebola while caring for the first U.S. patient to succumb to the deadly disease.
text: Judge Halts Worker's Comp Claim for Ebola Nurse Nina Pham A Texas district judge on Monday put on hold a hospital operator's efforts to seek a worker's compensation claim for a nurse who contracted Ebola while caring for the first U.S. patient to succumb to the deadly disease.

headline: Nurses Strike Called Off for University of Chicago
paragraph: A walkout by nurses at the University of Chicago Medical Center was averted after the healthcare workers reached a tentative agreement with administrators, but strikes are still planned at hospitals in California, the union said.
text: Nurses Strike Called Off for University of Chicago A walkout by nurses at the University of Chicago Medical Center was averted after the healthcare workers reached a tentative agreement with administrators, but strikes are still planned at hospitals in California, the union said.

headline: Nurses Union Plans Short Strikes in California and Illinois
paragraph: A union representing nurses in California and Illinois said on Monday 6,400 members planned to walk off their jobs later this week for a series of one- and two-day strikes amid contract negotiations.
text: Nurses Union Plans Short Strikes in California and Illinois A union representing nurses in California and Illinois said on Monday 6,400 members planned to walk off their jobs later this week for a series of one- and two-day strikes amid contract negotiations.

headline: Indiana Lawmakers OK Needle Exchange Programs
paragraph: Lawmakers looking to prevent a repeat of an HIV outbreak that has rocked a southern Indiana county sent Republican Gov. Mike Pence a measure Wednesday that would allow communities to implement needle-exchange programs if they can prove they're in the midst of an epidemic tied to intravenous drug use.
text: Indiana Lawmakers OK Needle Exchange Programs Lawmakers looking to prevent a repeat of an HIV outbreak that has rocked a southern Indiana county sent Republican Gov. Mike Pence a measure Wednesday that would allow communities to implement needle-exchange programs if they can prove they're in the midst of an epidemic tied to intravenous drug use.

headline: New York Attorney General Sues 2 Tanning Salon Chains
paragraph: New York's attorney general has filed suit against two tanning salon chains, accusing them of downplaying health risks while playing up the allure of bronze skin.
text: New York Attorney General Sues 2 Tanning Salon Chains New York's attorney general has filed suit against two tanning salon chains, accusing them of downplaying health risks while playing up the allure of bronze skin.

headline: US Shuts Down Ebola Treatment Center in Liberia
paragraph: American officials are shutting down a special treatment unit they set up in Liberia at the height of the Ebola crisis last year.
text: US Shuts Down Ebola Treatment Center in Liberia American officials are shutting down a special treatment unit they set up in Liberia at the height of the Ebola crisis last year.

headline: Source of Ohio Botulism Cases Likely Was Potato Salad
paragraph: Health officials say the likely source of the botulism outbreak that killed one person and sickened many others at an Ohio church potluck dinner was home-canned potatoes used in a potato salad.
text: Source of Ohio Botulism Cases Likely Was Potato Salad Health officials say the likely source of the botulism outbreak that killed one person and sickened many others at an Ohio church potluck dinner was home-canned potatoes used in a potato salad.

The Board of Trustees and leadership of Maimonides Medical Center mourn the loss of Jack Gallagher, a man of great vision who was the founding president and CEO of North Shore-LIJ Health System. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Aileen, his children and the entire Gallagher family at this time of loss. Martin D. Payson, Chair Emeritus Kenneth Gibbs, Chair Pamela S. Brier, President & CEO Maimonides Medical Center 1/3

headline: Chinese Babies Born During Pollution-Light Olympics Heavier
paragraph: Women in the Chinese capital in the final stage of pregnancy during the 2008 Beijing Olympics — when officials strictly controlled air pollution — gave birth to heavier babies than in years when the city was smoggier, a study said Wednesday.
text: Chinese Babies Born During Pollution-Light Olympics Heavier Women in the Chinese capital in the final stage of pregnancy during the 2008 Beijing Olympics — when officials strictly controlled air pollution — gave birth to heavier babies than in years when the city was smoggier, a study said Wednesday.

headline: Anthem CEO Says Obamacare Exchange Members 'Slightly Younger'
paragraph: Anthem Inc CEO Joseph Swedish said on Wednesday that the health insurer's new Obamacare exchange customers appear to be skewing "slightly younger" than in the past, which has positive implications for claims costs.
text: Anthem CEO Says Obamacare Exchange Members 'Slightly Younger' Anthem Inc CEO Joseph Swedish said on Wednesday that the health insurer's new Obamacare exchange customers appear to be skewing "slightly younger" than in the past, which has positive implications for claims costs.

headline: Technician in Fatal Case Forgot Prison Dialysis Appointment
paragraph: A dialysis technician forgot about an appointment at Utah's prison, where an inmate later died after going without treatment, the University of Utah's health care system said Wednesday.
text: Technician in Fatal Case Forgot Prison Dialysis Appointment A dialysis technician forgot about an appointment at Utah's prison, where an inmate later died after going without treatment, the University of Utah's health care system said Wednesday.

abstract: Study published in journal Nature Climate Change finds that carbon emissions standards proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency in 2015 for coal-fired power plants in United State will substantially improve human health and prevent thousands of premature deaths each year.
headline: E.P.A. Carbon Emissions Plan Could Save Thousands of Lives, Study Finds
paragraph: The carbon emissions standards, proposed last year for the nation’s coal-fired power plants, could prevent more than 3,000 premature deaths per year, according to a new study.
text: E.P.A. Carbon Emissions Plan Could Save Thousands of Lives, Study Finds The carbon emissions standards, proposed last year for the nation’s coal-fired power plants, could prevent more than 3,000 premature deaths per year, according to a new study. Study published in journal Nature Climate Change finds that carbon emissions standards proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency in 2015 for coal-fired power plants in United State will substantially improve human health and prevent thousands of premature deaths each year.

headline: Yemen Healthcare Services on Brink of Collapse, WHO Says
paragraph: Health services in Yemen are on the brink of collapse amid critical shortages of life-saving medicines, oxygen and fuel, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.
text: Yemen Healthcare Services on Brink of Collapse, WHO Says Health services in Yemen are on the brink of collapse amid critical shortages of life-saving medicines, oxygen and fuel, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.

headline: Republican Budget Seeks to Boost Defense Spending, Ease Repeal of Obamacare
paragraph: Republicans unveiled the first joint House-Senate budget plan in six years on Wednesday, aiming to boost defense spending, eliminate deficits by 2024 and ease a repeal of  President Barack Obama's signature health care reform law.
text: Republican Budget Seeks to Boost Defense Spending, Ease Repeal of Obamacare Republicans unveiled the first joint House-Senate budget plan in six years on Wednesday, aiming to boost defense spending, eliminate deficits by 2024 and ease a repeal of  President Barack Obama's signature health care reform law.

headline: CDC Official: HIV Outbreak Lessons May Spur 'Model Response'
paragraph: National health officials hope to use the lessons learned from efforts to contain an HIV outbreak in southern Indiana as "a model response" for the nation in combatting future outbreaks tied to intravenous drug use, a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention leader said Tuesday.

abstract: Undercover investigation by New York's State Liquor Authority finds that decoy minors were able to purchase alcohol at more than half of targeted pharmacies, grocery stores and liquor stores in New York City; department says it will take steps to reduce under-age alcohol consumption.

headline: Philips' Net Profit Slumps in 1st Quarter, Sales Edge Higher
paragraph: Royal Philips NV, the world's biggest lighting maker, said Tuesday higher restructuring costs wiped out gains from higher sales to reduce first-quarter net profit by 27 percent to 100 million euros ($109 million).
text: Philips' Net Profit Slumps in 1st Quarter, Sales Edge Higher Royal Philips NV, the world's biggest lighting maker, said Tuesday higher restructuring costs wiped out gains from higher sales to reduce first-quarter net profit by 27 percent to 100 million euros ($109 million).

abstract: Celebrity talk show host Dr Mehmet Oz plans to respond aggressively on The Dr Oz Show to letter sent by 10 physicians to Columbia University questioning Oz's position there as vice chairman of surgery department; letter criticized Oz's opposition to genetic engineering of food crops.

headline: HIV Outbreak in Indiana Affecting Residents' Quality of Life

It's a tidy appearance that masks a darker side of the community — the worst HIV outbreak in state history, which health officials warn hasn't yet peaked.

headline: Correction: Texas Prison-Riot Report Story
paragraph: In a story April 23 about a federal review of a West Texas prison, The Associated Press reported erroneously that The Geo Group, a company paid to run the Reeves County Detention Center, subcontracted out the prison's health services to another company. The company that runs the prison's health services was hired by the county, not The Geo Group.
text: Correction: Texas Prison-Riot Report Story In a story April 23 about a federal review of a West Texas prison, The Associated Press reported erroneously that The Geo Group, a company paid to run the Reeves County Detention Center, subcontracted out the prison's health services to another company. California Division of Occupational Safety and Health issues four citations to SeaWorld regarding orcas that total nearly $26,000 in fines.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MICHAEL
paragraph: KATZ--Michael. The Bay Terrace Garden Jewish Center mourns the tragic passing, on April 26, 2015, of Michael Katz, our dear friend, esteemed member, dedicated trustee and visionary past president. Michael's brilliance in so many fields of endeavor was matched by his courage and his groundbreaking and tireless advocacy for the health and well-being of those similarly afflicted with multiple myeloma. Michael was admired for his devotion to his loving wife Susan, his adoring children Jason (Sharon), Jeffrey (Dodie), Jonathan (Rebecca), grandchildren and extended family, his fierce loyalty to his many friends and his love of Judaism. His life will be an inspiration to us all. He will be sorely missed but never forgotten. Eli Koenig, M.D., Co-Pres. Marilyn Bitterman, Co-Pres. Rabbi Shlomo Blickstein Rabbi Emeritus, Hyman Levine Cantor Victor Wortman 1/3

headline: Red Cross Concerned About Rise in Afghan Civilian Casualties
paragraph: The International Committee of the Red Cross says it is concerned about a rise in civilian casualties as the Taliban wage their spring offensive.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, CAROLE
paragraph: SMITH--Carole, 78, of Park Slope, Brooklyn died April 9, 2015. She was born to the late Leo and Anna Fleck of Sheepshead Bay and was a graduate of James Madison High School and NYU. Carole taught foreign languages at Wingate High School, managed Public Relations for Abraham & Straus, and was a Respiratory Therapist at Bellevue Hospital before becoming the Director of The NYU School for Allied Health. A devoted wife, mother, friend, and teacher, Carole was passionate about helping people better their lives. She had a brilliant mind and loved reading, dining out, shopping, quilting, and travel. Carole was an expert collector and dealer of vintage jewelry. Survived by husband Robert Smith, daughter Amanda Reveno (Eric), son Lee Smith and two grandchildren. Preceded in death by son James Newman. Memorial donations may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation.

headline: Ukraine PM Says Welfare Boost Requires Economic Growth
paragraph: Ukraine's prime minister says there will be no increase to welfare payments until the poverty-stricken country emerges from its security and economic crisis.
text: Ukraine PM Says Welfare Boost Requires Economic Growth Ukraine's prime minister says there will be no increase to welfare payments until the poverty-stricken country emerges from its security and economic crisis.

headline: El Kabeir Scratched From Kentucky Derby
paragraph: El Kabeir, who excelled in prep races in New York, has an injury to his left front foot.
text: El Kabeir Scratched From Kentucky Derby El Kabeir, who excelled in prep races in New York, has an injury to his left front foot.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMBLE, FREDERICA
paragraph:
GAMBLE--Frederica

Vanderbilt (Webb), 101, died peacefully at her home in Westwood, MA on April 16th after a period of declining health. She is survived by her daughter, Frederica Gaynor Gamble, as well as nieces, nephews, cousins and friends, for whom she was an elegant and iconic presence. Born in Manhasset, NY, Freddy's family tree included Cornelius Vanderbilt, Webb generals from the Revolutionary and Civil Wars and her maternal grandfather, William Gaynor, who served as mayor of New York City. She projected this patrician heritage, leavened by humility and a keen sense of humor. After a marriage of 40 years her beloved husband David died too young, but well into her 80's she traveled the globe to explore and enjoy the wonders of the natural world. Hail and farewell. Contributions in Freddy's memory may be made to Shelburne Farms, 1611 Harbor Rd., Shelburne, VT 05482.

headline: Bill Clinton Begins Africa Tour in Tanzania
paragraph: Former U.S. President Bill Clinton on Wednesday started his tour of Africa with Tanzania, where he will visit projects funded by his foundation to boost agriculture, health, education and wildlife conservation.
text: Bill Clinton Begins Africa Tour in Tanzania Former U.S. President Bill Clinton on Wednesday started his tour of Africa with Tanzania, where he will visit projects funded by his foundation to boost agriculture, health, education and wildlife conservation.

headline: Saudi King Fires Protocol Chief After Photographer Slapped
paragraph: Saudi King Salman has fired the chief of royal protocol after he was caught on camera slapping a photographer.
text: Saudi King Fires Protocol Chief After Photographer Slapped Saudi King Salman has fired the chief of royal protocol after he was caught on camera slapping a photographer.

headline: 126 Migrants Reach Greek Shores, a Day After Fatal Sinking
paragraph: Greek authorities have picked up more than 120 migrants who illegally entered the country by sea on three separate vessels, a day after a yacht with 90 people on board foundered just off the island of Rhodes, drowning three.
text: 126 Migrants Reach Greek Shores, a Day After Fatal Sinking Greek authorities have picked up more than 120 migrants who illegally entered the country by sea on three separate vessels, a day after a yacht with 90 people on board foundered just off the island of Rhodes, drowning three.

headline: How the Dow Jones Industrial Average Fared Monday
paragraph: U.S. stocks slumped on Monday as investors looked ahead to a flurry of earnings reports this week. Health care companies led the declines. It was a downbeat note after strong gains last week, capped by a record in the Nasdaq composite, 15 years after its dot-com era peak.
text: How the Dow Jones Industrial Average Fared Monday U.S. stocks slumped on Monday as investors looked ahead to a flurry of earnings reports this week. Health care companies led the declines. It was a downbeat note after strong gains last week, capped by a record in the Nasdaq composite, 15 years after its dot-com era peak.

headline: Portugal Investigates Visas Awarded to Non-EU Investors

headline: Consumer Group Sues Cigna, Alleges Discrimination
paragraph: A consumer advocacy group has filed a class-action lawsuit against Cigna saying a new policy discriminates against people with HIV and AIDS and violates the federal health law by requiring them to get their medications from its mail-order pharmacy.
text: Consumer Group Sues Cigna, Alleges Discrimination A consumer advocacy group has filed a class-action lawsuit against Cigna saying a new policy discriminates against people with HIV and AIDS and violates the federal health law by requiring them to get their medications from its mail-order pharmacy.

headline: Aetna Beats Profit Forecasts
paragraph: Aetna has hiked its 2015 forecast beyond analyst expectations after booking a 17-percent jump in first-quarter earnings, as enrollment gains and moderate medical cost growth helped the nation's third-largest health insurer.
text: Aetna Beats Profit Forecasts Aetna has hiked its 2015 forecast beyond analyst expectations after booking a 17-percent jump in first-quarter earnings, as enrollment gains and moderate medical cost growth helped the nation's third-largest health insurer.

paragraph: Officials say they are closer to finding the source of botulism that killed one person and sickened many more after a church picnic in central Ohio last weekend.

headline: Louisiana Moves Ahead With Abortion Regulation Rewrite
paragraph: Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal's administration has rewritten the state's abortion clinic regulations, a move that abortion-rights supporters say was unnecessary and intended to hinder the operation of clinics.
text: Louisiana Moves Ahead With Abortion Regulation Rewrite Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal's administration has rewritten the state's abortion clinic regulations, a move that abortion-rights supporters say was unnecessary and intended to hinder the operation of clinics.

headline: Ferry Strikes Dock in Northwestern Greek Port; 11 Injured
paragraph: Greek authorities say a passenger ferry has struck the dock while tying up in the northwestern port of Igoumenitsa, leaving 11 people injured, including six children and two adults accompanying them on a school trip.
text: Ferry Strikes Dock in Northwestern Greek Port; 11 Injured Greek authorities say a passenger ferry has struck the dock while tying up in the northwestern port of Igoumenitsa, leaving 11 people injured, including six children and two adults accompanying them on a school trip.

headline: Turkish Plane Makes Emergency Landing
paragraph: A Turkish Airline official says a plane returning from Milan made an emergency landing in Istanbul and ran off the runway. The plane left a trail of sparks and smoke as it landed but all passengers were evacuated safely.
text: Turkish Plane Makes Emergency Landing A Turkish Airline official says a plane returning from Milan made an emergency landing in Istanbul and ran off the runway. The plane left a trail of sparks and smoke as it landed but all passengers were evacuated safely.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYD, JAMES W.
paragraph: BOYD--James W.,79, of Orleans, MA, passed away peacefully on February 4, 2015 in Port Orange, FL. Jim was born on May 8, 1935 in West Orange, NJ and was a graduate of The Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, Class of 1957. He was a Vice President at Morgan Guarantee Trust Co. for 22 years, and married Catherine H. Gallagher in 1998. Upon retirement they moved to Orleans, MA where they lived for 17 years. They spent their winters in Vero Beach and most recently Ponce Inlet, FL. Jim was an avid golfer and enjoyed the piano and entertaining his family and friends with an endless repertoire of Broadway show tunes. Jim's true dedication was to his family. He was the beloved husband of Catherine H. Gallagher Boyd, of Milton, NY, and the devoted father to Lisa Boyd Linton, James W. Boyd, Jr. and Alexander L. Boyd as well as the cherished grandfather of Chip Linton, Reese Linton, Sarah Boyd, Ellis Boyd, Alexandra Linton, Christopher Boyd and Graydon Boyd. He also leaves behind his loving step children Cathy Gallagher, Joy Gallagher, John Gallagher, and Tom Gallagher as well as four step grandchildren, Danielle, Julieann, Ryan and Jake. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, May 16, at 2pm at The Church of the Holy Spirit, 204 Monument Rd, Orleans, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Jim's memory to Hope Health, 765 Attucks Ln., Hyannis, MA 02601 or Halifax Health - Hospice, 3800 Woodbriar Trail, Port Orange, FL 32129. 1/3

headline: The ‘Missing’ Black Men
paragraph: Marc Mauer of the Sentencing Project cites “mass incarceration and early deaths” for the shocking numbers of “missing” black men.

abstract: Tyson Foods plans to eliminate use of human antibiotics from chicken production by 2017; move follows increased regulatory scrutiny and announcement by McDonalds that it would eliminate such antibiotics from its supply chains.
headline: Tyson to End Use of Human Antibiotics in Its Chickens by 2017
paragraph: The announcement by the meat producer, one of the country’s largest, comes as regulators grow increasingly concerned about antibiotics use in animal husbandry.
text: Tyson to End Use of Human Antibiotics in Its Chickens by 2017 The announcement by the meat producer, one of the country’s largest, comes as regulators grow increasingly concerned about antibiotics use in animal husbandry. Tyson Foods plans to eliminate use of human antibiotics from chicken production by 2017; move follows increased regulatory scrutiny and announcement by McDonalds that it would eliminate such antibiotics from its supply chains.

headline: Report: 5 Months After Infection, Man Spreads Ebola via Sex
paragraph: Health officials now think Ebola survivors can spread the disease through unprotected sex nearly twice as long as previously believed.
text: Report: 5 Months After Infection, Man Spreads Ebola via Sex Health officials now think Ebola survivors can spread the disease through unprotected sex nearly twice as long as previously believed.

headline: Amended China Law Curbs Tobacco Ads in Land of Smokers
paragraph: China's parliament has passed legislation that restricts tobacco advertising in public, strengthening efforts to curb smoking in a country where more than a billion people are smokers or exposed to second-hand smoke.
text: Amended China Law Curbs Tobacco Ads in Land of Smokers China's parliament has passed legislation that restricts tobacco advertising in public, strengthening efforts to curb smoking in a country where more than a billion people are smokers or exposed to second-hand smoke.

headline: Divestment Gains Boost Net Earnings at Drug Company Novartis
paragraph: Swiss-based pharmaceutical company Novartis reported a large jump in first-quarter net profit Thursday as it recorded one-time gains from deals with other drug companies.
text: Divestment Gains Boost Net Earnings at Drug Company Novartis Swiss-based pharmaceutical company Novartis reported a large jump in first-quarter net profit Thursday as it recorded one-time gains from deals with other drug companies.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERVIN, JUDITH
paragraph: ERVIN--Judith, (nee Tingerthal) died April 19, at age 70, from complications of Alzheimer's Disease. Born in St. Paul, MN, she graduated from the College of St. Catherine and earned an MBA from New York University. She spent her career in New York City, primarily working for Citicorp, where she retired as a vice-president in 2007. She traveled widely, enjoyed the cultural life of New York, and skied in Europe, at Killington and at Taos. After retiring, Judy became an enthusiastic volunteer for the Central Park Conservancy, an activity she continued well after her health started to decline. Her failing health caused her to leave her Central Park West condo and move closer to her family in Minnesota, where she passed away. She leaves behind her sisters and brothers, their spouses, her nieces and nephews and grand nieces and nephews. She also leaves her many friends, work colleagues and her neighbors at 392 CPW. Judy's family especially remembers the devotion of her friend and neighbor, Janet Smith, and her care-giver, Mary Folan. A funeral service will be held April 24 In Minneapolis, MN and burial will be at St. John's Cemetery in Collegeville, MN on May 2. A gathering to remember Judy's life is being planned for mid-June in New York City. Memorials are suggested to the Alzheimer's Association, the NC Little Hospice or the Central Park Conservancy.

headline: Sperm Bank Responds to Accusations It Misrepresented Donor

headline: Hundreds of Children Killed, Injured in 'Devastating' Yemen Conflict: U.N.
paragraph: A month of "devastating" conflict in Yemen has killed or injured hundreds of children, and dozens more have been mobilized as fighters, the United Nations children's agency UNICEF said on Friday.
text: Hundreds of Children Killed, Injured in 'Devastating' Yemen Conflict: U.N. A month of "devastating" conflict in Yemen has killed or injured hundreds of children, and dozens more have been mobilized as fighters, the United Nations children's agency UNICEF said on Friday.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYD, JAMES
paragraph: BOYD--James W., 79, of Orleans, MA, passed away peacefully on February 4, 2015 in Port Orange, FL. Jim was born on May 8, 1935 in West Orange, NJ and was a graduate of The Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, Class of 1957. He was a Vice President at Morgan Guarantee Trust Co. for 22 years, and married Catherine H. Gallagher in 1998. Upon retirement they moved to Orleans, MA where they lived for 17 years. They spent their winters in Vero Beach and most recently Ponce Inlet, FL. Jim was an avid golfer and enjoyed the piano and entertaining his family and friends with an endless repertoire of Broadway show tunes. Jim's true dedication was to his family. He was the beloved husband of Catherine H. Gallagher Boyd, of Milton, NY, and the devoted father to Lisa Boyd Linton, James W. Boyd, Jr. and Alexander L. Boyd as well as the cherished grandfather of Chip Linton, Reese Linton, Sarah Boyd, Ellis Boyd, Alexandra Linton, Christopher Boyd and Graydon Boyd. He also leaves behind his loving step children Cathy Gallagher, Joy Gallagher, John Gallagher, and Tom Gallagher as well as four step grandchildren, Danielle, Julieann, Ryan and Jake. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, May 16, at 2pm at The Church of the Holy Spirit, 204 Monument Rd, Orleans, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Jim's memory to Hope Health, 765 Attucks Ln., Hyannis, MA 02601 or Halifax Health - Hospice, 3800 Woodbriar Trail, Port Orange, FL 32129.

headline: UN Says It Will Try to Identify All Ebola Cases by June

text: UN Says It Will Try to Identify All Ebola Cases by June The World Health Organization says it aims to identify and isolate all new Ebola cases in West Africa by the end of May to stop the spread of the lethal virus before the rainy season.

headline: Indiana HIV Cases Reach 142 in Rural Outbreak, More Expected

text: Indiana HIV Cases Reach 142 in Rural Outbreak, More Expected The number of confirmed and presumed HIV cases stemming from abuse of intravenous prescription drugs has increased to 142 in a rural part of southeastern Indiana and more cases are being identified every day, a state health official said on Friday.

headline: Coca Production in Colombia Jumped 39 Pct in 2014
paragraph: Cultivation of the leaf used to make cocaine skyrocketed last year in Colombia, according to a new White House report that's likely to pressure the government to preserve a threatened U.S. aerial eradication program that's been at the heart of the drug war for over a decade.

headline: Shi'ite Militia Hands Over Suspected Body of Former Top Saddam Aide

headline: Study: Cutting Carbon Dioxide Saves 3,500 US Lives a Year
paragraph: The Obama Administration's hotly debated plan to reduce heat-trapping carbon dioxide from the nation's power plants will save about 3,500 lives a year by cutting back on other types of pollution as well, a new independent study concludes.
text: Study: Cutting Carbon Dioxide Saves 3,500 US Lives a Year The Obama Administration's hotly debated plan to reduce heat-trapping carbon dioxide from the nation's power plants will save about 3,500 lives a year by cutting back on other types of pollution as well, a new independent study concludes.

headline: Regulators Fine SeaWorld San Diego Over Worker Safety: Newspaper
paragraph: California safety regulators have fined SeaWorld San Diego for not properly instructing workers on how to "safely interact with killer whales," the Los Angeles Times reported on Thursday.
text: Regulators Fine SeaWorld San Diego Over Worker Safety: Newspaper California safety regulators have fined SeaWorld San Diego for not properly instructing workers on how to "safely interact with killer whales," the Los Angeles Times reported on Thursday.

headline: Illness Memoir 'The Iceberg' Wins Wellcome Book Prize

abstract: Native American community in South Dakota's Pine Ridge Reservation is experiencing suicide crisis, with nine people between 12 and 24 years old killing themselves in period beginning December 2014; emergency workers on reservation describe being called to scenes of suicide attempts, sometimes several times per day; some attribute trend to dire lack of mental health professionals and youth culture that has begun encouraging suicide through urban legends and disturbing Internet videos.

paragraph: Since December, nine people between 12 and 24 years old have killed themselves on the South Dakota reservation, and many others have tried.

abstract: Pres Obama signs bill ending use of Social Security numbers on more than 50 million benefit cards, move that addresses rise in frequency and sophistication of identity theft; Medicare officials will have up to four years to begin issuing new benefit cards; effort is part of a broader measure intended to overhaul way doctors are paid for treating Medicare patients.

abstract: Environmental Protection Agency faces strong opposition as it prepares to establish first robust regulation of formaldehyde in consumer products; five-year effort to adopt new rules highlights how industry opposition can hamper regulation even when substances are known to be deeply harmful; key elements of proposal have already been eliminated amid lobbying effort.

abstract: Report by group of dissident mental health professionals and activists alleges that American Psychological Assn secretly collaborated with George W Bush administration to provide legal and ethical justification for torture in wake of Sept 11 attacks; APA denies any such coordination, but is awaiting results of internal review; report says presence of APA psychologists allowed administration to salvage interrogation program at time of deep public scrutiny in 2004.

abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column holds character trait most valuable in nation's next president should be a willingness to reassess commonly-held perceptions and admit wrongdoing; laments this open-mindedness is generally lambasted in media, and referred to as 'flip-flopping' rather than applauded as learning from experience; says while issues instead of character should have greater focus in campaign, this intellectual integrity is essential in a leader.

abstract: Editorial supports bill sponsored by Congressional Democrats that would raise minimum wage from $7.25 an hour to $12 an hour by 2020; cites research showing majority of people in public assistance programs like Medicaid and food stamps are in families headed by a low-wage worker; says this places economic burden on taxpayers while corporations paying low wages are enjoying benefits of nation's productivity gains.

headline: Sri Lanka Ex-President Rajapaksa Refuses to Attend Anti-Graft Body
paragraph: Former Sri Lankan president Mahinda Rajapaksa will not appear before an anti-bribery commission investigating allegations that he may have illegally induced a rival to support his campaign during the recent presidential elections.Rajapaksa will ignore a summons to appear on April 24 because the exact nature of the complaint and the person making the allegations have not been disclosed, Rohan Weliwita, Rajapaksa's media adviser, told Reuters."He is consulting his legal team on the summons," Weliwita said.   The allegations are the latest in a series of corruption charges made against Rajapaksa by Sri Lanka's new government, which has ordered an investigation into all the financial deals he made during his decade in power.
text: Sri Lanka Ex-President Rajapaksa Refuses to Attend Anti-Graft Body Former Sri Lankan president Mahinda Rajapaksa will not appear before an anti-bribery commission investigating allegations that he may have illegally induced a rival to support his campaign during the recent presidential elections.Rajapaksa will ignore a summons to appear on April 24 because the exact nature of the complaint and the person making the allegations have not been disclosed, Rohan Weliwita, Rajapaksa's media adviser, told Reuters."He is consulting his legal team on the summons," Weliwita said.   The allegations are the latest in a series of corruption charges made against Rajapaksa by Sri Lanka's new government, which has ordered an investigation into all the financial deals he made during his decade in power.

headline: Southeast Asian Leaders Urged to Act on Rohingya Crisis

headline: Olympic Champion Bruce Jenner Sued for Wrongful Death in Car Crash

headline: Sri Lanka Parliament Passes Diluted Reforms

headline: A Space Odyssey: Cosmic Rays May Damage the Brains of Astronauts

headline: AP PHOTOS: Peruvian Community Lives Half-Year on the Water
paragraph: Residents of the Peruvian Amazon community nicknamed "Venice of the Jungle" live half the year on the water, with canoes replacing motorcycle taxis as the most popular form of transport. Teenagers swim in the same areas where they played soccer during the other six months of the year.

headline: 'American Sniper' Widow Taya Kyle's New Book Addresses Grief
paragraph: The widow of "American Sniper" author Chris Kyle says in her new book that her stance on the death penalty was among things she struggled with after he was killed in 2013.
text: 'American Sniper' Widow Taya Kyle's New Book Addresses Grief The widow of "American Sniper" author Chris Kyle says in her new book that her stance on the death penalty was among things she struggled with after he was killed in 2013.

headline: Sri Lanka Parliament Passes Diluted Reforms
paragraph: Sri Lanka’s parliament overwhelmingly passed reforms on Tuesday reducing some of the president’s powers, in a move that did not go as far as President Maithripala Sirisena had promised but is nevertheless seen as a victory for the leader.
text: Sri Lanka Parliament Passes Diluted Reforms Sri Lanka’s parliament overwhelmingly passed reforms on Tuesday reducing some of the president’s powers, in a move that did not go as far as President Maithripala Sirisena had promised but is nevertheless seen as a victory for the leader.

headline: Fiancée Chronicles Love, Life With Man Who Died of Ebola in Texas
paragraph: Thomas Eric Duncan became the face of a crisis when he was diagnosed with Ebola in the United States, but he was simply "Eric" to his fiancee, Louise Troh, who said she has endured threats and battled nightmares since his death in October.

abstract: Midwestern poultry farms are being swept by avian influenza, with more than 20 million chickens and other birds already dead or culled in effort to stop spread of illness; health officials are preparing for possibility that latest avian flu virus, which is related to Asian H5N1 flu virus that has killed 440 people in Asia, could spread to humans; experts caution that risk to humans is low but are taking threat seriously and encouraging preparations.
headline: A Flu Epidemic That Threatens Birds, Not Humans
paragraph: An avian virus related to one that has killed 440 people in Asia is cutting through the Midwest. But experts say the risk to humans is low.
text: A Flu Epidemic That Threatens Birds, Not Humans An avian virus related to one that has killed 440 people in Asia is cutting through the Midwest. But experts say the risk to humans is low. Midwestern poultry farms are being swept by avian influenza, with more than 20 million chickens and other birds already dead or culled in effort to stop spread of illness; health officials are preparing for possibility that latest avian flu virus, which is related to Asian H5N1 flu virus that has killed 440 people in Asia, could spread to humans; experts caution that risk to humans is low but are taking threat seriously and encouraging preparations.

abstract: Blue Bell Creameries, nation's third-largest ice cream brand, recalls all of its frozen desserts and shuts registers at all 300 of its stores due to potential listeria contamination; rapid pace of recall highlights seriousness of threat, and represents biggest crisis in brand's 108-year history; some analysts say despite rare urgency and scope of recall, Blue Bell acted too late to prevent erosion of customer confidence.

headline: APNewsBreak: Officer Who Shot Man Dragged Him From Fire

headline: Part-Time 'Slack' May Be Nearing Its End as Fed Debates Hike
paragraph: U.S. part-time employment is fast-approaching levels common since the 1970s in a sign that a key part of labor market slack may be almost gone, giving the Fed one less reason to delay hiking interest rates frozen near zero for more than six years.

abstract: Thousands of women who contend they were seriously hurt by contraceptive implant Essure are asking Food and Drug Admin to remove device from market and warn public about its complications; disturbing long-term data on women using device is published in Journal of Minimally Invasive Gynecology after eight-year delay.

headline: Kazakh Leader Sails to New Term With 'Stability' Mantra
paragraph: Nursultan Nazarbayev was heading for a virtually unchallenged victory in Kazakhstan's presidential election on Sunday, offering  economic and social stability at the cost of what rights groups call systematic stifling of dissent over his 26-year rule.

abstract: Editorial applauds Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel's plan to provide reparations for scores of mainly African-American men tortured by police under commander Jon Burge in 1970s and '80s; holds recent shooting of black teenager Laquan McDonald and subsequent $5 million settlement with his family point to continued failings of city's police force; urges public release of police dash-cam footage of McDonald shooting as means of ensuring transparency and regaining public trust.

abstract: American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois and Illinois Department of Juvenile Justice reach agreement that sharply limits practice of solitary confinement in juvenile correctional facilities; new policy requires that juvenile inmates spend at least eight hours a day outside their cells and that inmates in isolation continue to receive education and mental health services.

headline: With Nasdaq in Record Territory, What It Means for 401(k)s
paragraph: Technology stocks are trading at levels not seen since Y2K and that may trigger some bad memories. After all, the last time the index reached a record high it quickly plummeted in what became known as at the dot-com crash.

headline: CDC Eyeing Bird Flu Vaccine for Humans, Though Risk Is Low
paragraph: Federal officials said Wednesday they're taking steps to create a human vaccine for the bird flu virus that's slammed the Midwest poultry industry, though they still consider the danger to be low and the food supply not at risk.
text: CDC Eyeing Bird Flu Vaccine for Humans, Though Risk Is Low Federal officials said Wednesday they're taking steps to create a human vaccine for the bird flu virus that's slammed the Midwest poultry industry, though they still consider the danger to be low and the food supply not at risk.

headline: US Intervenes in Whistleblower Cases Against Nursing Homes
paragraph: The Justice Department said Tuesday that it is stepping into a long-running lawsuit against one of the nation's largest nursing-home chains, accusing it of systematic Medicare overbilling and sometimes putting frail, dying patients through arduous rehab schedules just to increase revenue.
text: US Intervenes in Whistleblower Cases Against Nursing Homes The Justice Department said Tuesday that it is stepping into a long-running lawsuit against one of the nation's largest nursing-home chains, accusing it of systematic Medicare overbilling and sometimes putting frail, dying patients through arduous rehab schedules just to increase revenue.

text: Labor Group Seeks Rehiring of Workers at 5 Walmart Stores A union is asking labor regulators to go to court to force Walmart to rehire all 2,200 employees affected by the abrupt temporary closing of five stores a week ago.

headline: SeaWorld Cited Over Safety of Trainers Who Work With Orcas
paragraph: SeaWorld — whose safety practices have been under scrutiny since an animal trainer was killed in 2010 by an orca at its Orlando, Florida, park — has now been cited for not adequately protecting its killer-whale trainers at its park in San Diego.
text: SeaWorld Cited Over Safety of Trainers Who Work With Orcas SeaWorld — whose safety practices have been under scrutiny since an animal trainer was killed in 2010 by an orca at its Orlando, Florida, park — has now been cited for not adequately protecting its killer-whale trainers at its park in San Diego.

abstract: Gilead Sciences reports surging first quarter profits, with earnings per share more than doubling to $2.76 from year-earlier period; reports that sales of its hepatitis C drugs reached $4.55 billion, largely reflecting popularity of its new drug, Harvoni.

headline: Settlement Reached in 2003 Connecticut Layoff Lawsuit

headline: Most Weapons Found in NYC Jails Are Homemade, Report Shows
paragraph: Nearly 80 percent of the 2,100 weapons recovered in New York City jails last year were shivs and shanks made from materials scrounged in the jailhouse, according to a new report that advocates say is at odds with the official view that smuggled razors are behind a recent surge in stabbings and slashings.
text: Most Weapons Found in NYC Jails Are Homemade, Report Shows Nearly 80 percent of the 2,100 weapons recovered in New York City jails last year were shivs and shanks made from materials scrounged in the jailhouse, according to a new report that advocates say is at odds with the official view that smuggled razors are behind a recent surge in stabbings and slashings.

abstract: Anheuser-Bush InBev incurs widespread ire from women after placing controversial label on some of its Bud Light bottles; language, which suggests beer helps remove word 'no' from a drinker's vocabulary, is seen as deeply insensitive in light of public outcry over campus rape.

headline: 60 Bodies Recovered in Nepal Valley Hit by Quake, Mudslide

abstract: Iowa jury finds Henry Rayhons not guilty of charges he sexually abused his wife Donna, an Alzheimer's patient, by having physical relations with her after being told she was medically unable to give consent; Rayhons had faced up to 10 years in prison on felony charge, and his case ignited national debate over ability of dementia patients to consent to sexual intimacy.
headline: Iowa Man Found Not Guilty of Sexually Abusing Wife With Alzheimer’s

text: Iowa Man Found Not Guilty of Sexually Abusing Wife With Alzheimer’s Henry Rayhons was accused of sexually abusing his wife in a nursing home after staff members told him she had become cognitively unable to give consent. Iowa jury finds Henry Rayhons not guilty of charges he sexually abused his wife Donna, an Alzheimer's patient, by having physical relations with her after being told she was medically unable to give consent; Rayhons had faced up to 10 years in prison on felony charge, and his case ignited national debate over ability of dementia patients to consent to sexual intimacy.

headline: Spain: Student Armed With Crossbow, Machete Kills Teacher

abstract: California legislation that would require almost all children in state to be vaccinated unless a valid medical reason is proven moves forward in State Legislature; if bill passes several more committee hurdles, California could become one of only three states in nation requiring vaccinations as a condition for attending public or private schools.

headline: Merck Earnings Beat Forecasts

text: Merck Earnings Beat Forecasts Drugmaker Merck & Co. easily beat Wall Street expectations, sending its shares up sharply, despite first-quarter profit plunging 44 percent. headline: Panel Detail Lee's Negligent Practices in Doping Case
paragraph: For seven years, Lee Chong Wei, one of badminton's finest athletes, took cordyceps tablets from unmarked containers on the advice of a mysterious friend without any knowledge of how they were capsulated or stored.
text: Panel Detail Lee's Negligent Practices in Doping Case For seven years, Lee Chong Wei, one of badminton's finest athletes, took cordyceps tablets from unmarked containers on the advice of a mysterious friend without any knowledge of how they were capsulated or stored.

headline: Spain Spends Its Way Back to Growth but Recovery Needs More Fuel
paragraph: At Diego Manrique's second-hand car dealership on the outskirts of Madrid, business is picking up. A long economic crisis has over the months brought many prospective buyers to appraise his cheap deals - but now they are actually handing over money.

abstract: California legislation that would require almost all children in state to be vaccinated unless a valid medical reason is proven moves forward in State Legislature; if bill passes several more committee hurdles, California could become one of only three states in nation requiring vaccinations as a condition for attending public or private schools.

paragraph: The legislation, which would eliminate so-called personal belief exemptions, still has to clear several hurdles before it can become law.

headline: 5 Nursing Students Killed in Georgia Interstate Crash
paragraph: Five nursing students died early Wednesday in a chain-reaction crash in southeast Georgia that authorities said began when a tractor-trailer failed to slow down and smashed into stop-and-go traffic.

headline: Political Insiders Benefit From Tax Break on UK Party Giving
paragraph: When British businessman Robert Durward decided to spend 1.9 million pounds ($2.9 million) funding a new free-market political party in the mid-2000s, friends said he was wasting his money. Years after his "New Party" collapsed, he agrees, telling Reuters it was "a complete and utter waste of time."

headline: Connecticut Urged to Consider Euthanizing Rescued Goats
paragraph: After rescuing dozens of neglected, malnourished goats this winter, the state of Connecticut is being asked whether the costs involved in their care are worth keeping them alive.
text: Connecticut Urged to Consider Euthanizing Rescued Goats After rescuing dozens of neglected, malnourished goats this winter, the state of Connecticut is being asked whether the costs involved in their care are worth keeping them alive.

headline: Circus Returns to Rhode Island Year After Hair-Hanging Fall
paragraph: The last time Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey circus performed in Rhode Island, eight acrobats suspended by their hair plummeted to the ground before a crowd of thousands. A single metal clip that held them 20 feet aloft had snapped. The women were badly hurt, some with spinal injuries so severe they could no longer walk.

paragraph: A massive earthquake in Nepal has exposed the woeful state of its medical facilities as hospitals struggle to treat vast numbers of injured with limited supplies and staff.

headline: WNBA's Griner, Fiancee Glory Johnson Arrested After Fight

headline: Exclusive: Siemens Healthcare Unit Probed by China Regulator for Bribery-Sources
paragraph: A Chinese regulator investigated Siemens AG last year over whether the German group's healthcare unit and its dealers bribed hospitals to buy expensive disposable products used in some of its medical devices, three people with knowledge of the probe told Reuters.

abstract: Editorial underscores damage done to Gulf of Mexico by 2010 BP oil spill and warns of lasting and continuing consequences, despite BP reports suggesting otherwise; points out that spill has yielded some unlikely benefits, including overhaul of drilling regulations and large environmental fund built from BP fines; urges officials to ensure that funds are used to replenish gulf's fragile ecosystem.
headline: The Gulf, Still at Risk
paragraph: The penalties BP will have to pay in restoration may finally give the Gulf of Mexico’s fragile ecosystem the long-term care it needs.
text: The Gulf, Still at Risk  The penalties BP will have to pay in restoration may finally give the Gulf of Mexico’s fragile ecosystem the long-term care it needs. Editorial underscores damage done to Gulf of Mexico by 2010 BP oil spill and warns of lasting and continuing consequences, despite BP reports suggesting otherwise; points out that spill has yielded some unlikely benefits, including overhaul of drilling regulations and large environmental fund built from BP fines; urges officials to ensure that funds are used to replenish gulf's fragile ecosystem.

headline: Last Chance for Cameron and Miliband to Break UK Election Deadlock

paragraph: After losing top engineering talent for years to America's tech heartland of Silicon Valley, India is luring them back as an e-commerce boom sparks a thriving start-up culture, unprecedented pay, and perks including free healthcare for in-laws.

headline: $4 Million in US Projects Aim to Protect Sage Grouse Habitat
paragraph: Interior Secretary Sally Jewell on Wednesday announced more than $4 million in projects in four states as part of a wildfire-fighting strategy to protect a wide swath of intermountain West sagebrush country that supports cattle ranching and is home to a struggling bird species.

headline: Legal Pot in California? Taxes, Black Market Pose Challenges

headline: Union Seeks Labor Board Injunction Over Wal-Mart Store Closings

headline: Month-Long Protest Over Peru Copper Mine Claims First Life

headline: Advocate: 5 Asylum Seekers on Nauru Set to Go to Cambodia
paragraph: Five asylum seekers from Sri Lanka, Myanmar and Iran have agreed to be among the first to leave the Pacific island nation of Nauru for Cambodia under a deal that allows refugees rejected by Australia to be resettled in the Southeast Asian country, a refugee advocate said Monday.

headline: Kazakh Leader Apologizes for 97.7 Percent Re-election Victory
paragraph: Kazakhstan's long-serving President Nursultan Nazarbayev apologized on Monday for winning re-election with 97.7 percent of the vote, saying it would have "looked undemocratic" for him to intervene to make his victory more modest.
text: Kazakh Leader Apologizes for 97.7 Percent Re-election Victory Kazakhstan's long-serving President Nursultan Nazarbayev apologized on Monday for winning re-election with 97.7 percent of the vote, saying it would have "looked undemocratic" for him to intervene to make his victory more modest.

headline: Strong Dollar Squeezes Company Earnings
paragraph: Procter & Gamble and Facebook seem to have nothing in common. One deals in razors and toothpaste, the other in "likes," self-promotion and embarrassing family photos. But this week, they shared the same problem: the strong dollar took a cut of their quarterly sales.

abstract: Silicon Valley start-up Color Genomics is set to announce inexpensive genetic screening for breast cancer that uses patient's saliva, at same time Quest Diagnostics and LabCorp will announce joint research effort on breast cancer risk genes; announcements mark surge in genetics risk screening competition unleashed by 2013 Supreme Court decision invalidating Myriad Genetics' monopoly on BRCA testing; question of who should be tested for risk remains controversial.

abstract: Norwegian researcher Pal-Orjan Johansen is pushing for legalization of psychedelic drug LSD, as well as MDMA and psilocybin, substances banned in many countries around world; EmmaSofia, advocacy group Johansen formed with his wife Teri Krebs, has gained surprising amount of support in drug-averse nation, demonstrating momentum of growing effort to revise drug policies of 1970s.

headline: On Clinton's Age, Republican Rivals Imply -- but Never Say -- She's Old
paragraph: Her campaign barely three weeks old, Hillary Clinton already has been attacked by Republicans on everything from donations to her family's charitable foundation, to her tenure as secretary of state and her ties to Wall Street. But her rivals, and the political action committees that support them, are treading more carefully on one incendiary subject: her age.

headline: Saudi King Recasts Line of Succession With Eye on Security
paragraph: Saudi Arabia's King Salman redrew the line of succession on Wednesday, appointing a counterterrorism czar as crown prince and placing his own defense minister son in line for the crown — a dramatic reshuffle that reflects the kingdom's mounting security concerns and more assertive foreign policy.

abstract: Economists, investors and European regulators have come to something like consensus that no one understands how global markets will react if Greece defaults on its debt; possibility has become more concrete in light of impasse reached between Greek government and its creditors, and high degree of uncertainty may be worst possible situation for investors.
headline: Uncertainty Over Impact of a Default by Greece
paragraph: Regulators, investors and economists are starting to conclude that after five years of endless analysis and speculation, no one really knows how the markets will react to a Greek default.

Economists, investors and European regulators have come to something like consensus that no one understands how global markets will react if Greece defaults on its debt; possibility has become more concrete in light of impasse reached between Greek government and its creditors, and high degree of uncertainty may be worst possible situation for investors.

headline: New Meds Help Drugmakers Weather Strong Dollar, Other Issues
paragraph: Revenue from important new medicines for various cancers, hepatitis C and more helped top U.S. drugmakers weather unfavorable currency exchange rates and other challenges. Pfizer Inc., Merck & Co. and Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., which reported first-quarter results Tuesday, all derive at least half their revenue from selling products overseas. Because they're purchased in local currencies, the strong dollar is depressing the sales' value.

abstract: Op-Ed article by New America senior fellow Lee Drutman submits that increasing funding to Congress and its research arms is better way to counter corporate influence in government than caps on corporate spending on political influence; holds that low government salaries result in high turnover rate among committee staff members, who often leave to become lobbyists; says solution is not to reduce number of lobbyists but to balance them on government side.

paragraph: Saudi-led coalition warplanes bombed Yemen on Wednesday despite an announcement by Riyadh that it was ending its campaign of air strikes, while renewed fighting erupted on the ground between rebels and forces loyal to the exiled president.

abstract: Op-Ed article by policy expert Jeffrey D Sachs argues that devastating earthquake in Nepal points up need for new global system of insurance for natural disasters; holds international response in such cases usually amounts to desperate patchwork that fails to result in long-term rebuilding effort; outlines system that would provide insurance in open markets with cost-sharing by international agencies like the World Bank.
headline: Insuring for Disaster

abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column welcomes announcement by Sen Bernie Sanders, independent of Vermont, of his official candidacy in 2016 race for Democratic presidential nomination; acknowledges Sanders's consistency on issues over time but holds he is too far left to be significant threat to Hillary Rodham Clinton; suggests that his entry should at least keep Clinton on her toes and make race more interesting.

headline: South Africa's Image Suffers After Anti-Immigrant Attacks
paragraph: Only a few kilometers (miles) separate Alexandra, a gritty Johannesburg township where South Africans attacked immigrants last week, from Sandton, a district jammed with high-end stores, restaurants and gleaming office towers symbolizing the upper reaches of the prosperity that attracted so many job-seekers to South Africa.

headline: High-Tech Sensors Help Kids Keep Eye on Aging Parents

headline: Weight Watchers Founder Jean Nidetch Dies at Age 91
paragraph: A half-century after dropping 70 pounds and keeping them off, Weight Watchers founder Jean Nidetch made some allowances: Cokes in her fridge, Klondikes in her freezer, the occasional potato or extra piece of bread on her plate. But she never again touched the chocolate marshmallow cookies she called her ultimate weakness, the treat she'd stash in the hamper and eat by the boxful in the middle of the night, all the while praying she'd choke on her next bite.
text: Weight Watchers Founder Jean Nidetch Dies at Age 91 A half-century after dropping 70 pounds and keeping them off, Weight Watchers founder Jean Nidetch made some allowances: Cokes in her fridge, Klondikes in her freezer, the occasional potato or extra piece of bread on her plate. But she never again touched the chocolate marshmallow cookies she called her ultimate weakness, the treat she'd stash in the hamper and eat by the boxful in the middle of the night, all the while praying she'd choke on her next bite.

abstract: Deutsche Bank agrees to pay $2.5 billion to settle charges that it manipulated worldwide interest rates as part of Libor scandal; settlement is largest yet of its kind, and will include criminal guilty plea for British subsidiary at center of case; deal will require termination of certain employees, but no individual at Deutsche Bank has yet been criminally charged.

abstract: Pope Francis accepts resignation of Bishop Robert W Finn as head of Diocese of Kansas City-St Joseph in Missouri following scandal over Finn's failure to report priest who took pornographic pictures of girls; event represents first time Francis has held American bishop accountable for actions of pedophile priest and raises question of whether Francis will pursue such actions around globe.

paragraph: Bishop Robert W. Finn was the highest-ranking American church official found guilty of a crime related to a child sexual abuse scandal.
text: Robert Finn, Missouri Bishop Convicted of Shielding Pedophile Priest, Resigns Bishop Robert W. Finn was the highest-ranking American church official found guilty of a crime related to a child sexual abuse scandal. Pope Francis accepts resignation of Bishop Robert W Finn as head of Diocese of Kansas City-St Joseph in Missouri following scandal over Finn's failure to report priest who took pornographic pictures of girls; event represents first time Francis has held American bishop accountable for actions of pedophile priest and raises question of whether Francis will pursue such actions around globe.

abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column recounts her experience of admonishing her niece Tara to get a second medical opinion after being diagnosed at ER with a stroke; notes that Tara, initially told she needed to move with care, is now engaging in the active lifestyle she enjoyed prior to her stroke.
headline: Stroke of Fate
paragraph: A wife and mom faces an identity crisis after having a stroke only months after turning 40.
text: Stroke of Fate  A wife and mom faces an identity crisis after having a stroke only months after turning 40. Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column recounts her experience of admonishing her niece Tara to get a second medical opinion after being diagnosed at ER with a stroke; notes that Tara, initially told she needed to move with care, is now engaging in the active lifestyle she enjoyed prior to her stroke.

abstract: New York Times South Asia bureau chief Ellen Barry answers readers' questions about conditions in Nepal following major earthquake.

headline: 'Batman' Killer Studied Brain Disorders Before Mass Murder
