abstract: House passes bill that would urge companies to safely share access to their computer networks and records with federal investigators; if House and Senate agree on final version, legislation would represent government's strongest action yet in response to wave of damaging computer attacks against the likes of Sony Pictures, Target stores and health insurer Anthem.
headline: House Passes Cybersecurity Bill After Companies Fall Victim to Data Breaches
paragraph: It was the government’s most aggressive response yet to a spate of computer attacks on targets including Sony Pictures Entertainment and the health insurer Anthem.
text: House Passes Cybersecurity Bill After Companies Fall Victim to Data Breaches It was the government’s most aggressive response yet to a spate of computer attacks on targets including Sony Pictures Entertainment and the health insurer Anthem. House passes bill that would urge companies to safely share access to their computer networks and records with federal investigators; if House and Senate agree on final version, legislation would represent government's strongest action yet in response to wave of damaging computer attacks against the likes of Sony Pictures, Target stores and health insurer Anthem.

headline: How Countries Cope With Migrants Arriving by Boat
paragraph: Two recent shipwrecks in the Mediterranean Sea believed to have taken the lives of as many as 1,300 asylum seekers and migrants highlight the growing number of people fleeing persecution, war and economic difficulties in their homelands.
text: How Countries Cope With Migrants Arriving by Boat Two recent shipwrecks in the Mediterranean Sea believed to have taken the lives of as many as 1,300 asylum seekers and migrants highlight the growing number of people fleeing persecution, war and economic difficulties in their homelands.

abstract: Grace Notes column; profile of Helen Anea Salcedo, Queens woman who was abducted as a 2-month-old in 1994 from her mother's workplace in East New York, Brooklyn; Salcedo recalls being about 10 years old when her mother first told her about events that shocked city.
headline: Abducted as an Infant, Revisiting It as an Adult
paragraph: In August 1994, the city turned itself upside down looking for a 2-month-old girl who was snatched from her mother at her job in Brooklyn.

headline: For Asylum Seekers, a Novel (and Odd) Solution: Cambodia

abstract: Scientists are trying to understand evolutionary reason why chlorophyll in plants reflects only green light, making plants appear green to human eye; humans are hard-wired to be drawn to color green, perhaps legacy of visual system that evolved in sea-dwelling ancestors.
headline: Our Ever Green World
paragraph: Humans are innately sensitive to a color that pervades nature and prompts a variety of emotional responses.
text: Our Ever Green World Humans are innately sensitive to a color that pervades nature and prompts a variety of emotional responses. Scientists are trying to understand evolutionary reason why chlorophyll in plants reflects only green light, making plants appear green to human eye; humans are hard-wired to be drawn to color green, perhaps legacy of visual system that evolved in sea-dwelling ancestors.

headline: As Petrobras Scandal Spreads, Economic Toll Mounts for Brazil
paragraph: For the 20 men hanging on at the Pousada do Trabalhador, a 600-bed boarding house on the dusty outskirts of this boom town northeast of Rio de Janeiro, the dream that Brazil's oil wealth would bring a better life was over.

abstract: Op-Ed article by economists Alex Peysakhovich and Seth Stephens-Davidowitz enumerates ways big data does not lead to a better life; notes what is needed is human element in form of surveys, or small data, to contribute to efficacy of patterns discovered by big data.
headline: How Not to Drown in Numbers
paragraph: The key question isn’t “What did I measure?” but “What did I miss?”
text: How Not to Drown in Numbers The key question isn’t “What did I measure?” but “What did I miss?” Op-Ed article by economists Alex Peysakhovich and Seth Stephens-Davidowitz enumerates ways big data does not lead to a better life; notes what is needed is human element in form of surveys, or small data, to contribute to efficacy of patterns discovered by big data.

abstract: Pharmaceuticals are racing to develop first drugs for celiac disease, condition that is now understood to be far more common than previously thought; drugs, which will not reach market until at least 2018, would not eliminate need for gluten-free diet, but could alleviate symptoms from trace elements; Food and Drug Admin is moving to develop standards for measuring drugs' effectiveness.
headline: As Celiac and Gluten Sensitivities Gain Prominence, Drug Companies Race to Find Treatments
paragraph: It’s estimated that about three million Americans have celiac disease. And even though a gluten-free diet can help alleviate symptoms, it’s not a cure-all.
text: As Celiac and Gluten Sensitivities Gain Prominence, Drug Companies Race to Find Treatments It’s estimated that about three million Americans have celiac disease. And even though a gluten-free diet can help alleviate symptoms, it’s not a cure-all. Pharmaceuticals are racing to develop first drugs for celiac disease, condition that is now understood to be far more common than previously thought; drugs, which will not reach market until at least 2018, would not eliminate need for gluten-free diet, but could alleviate symptoms from trace elements; Food and Drug Admin is moving to develop standards for measuring drugs' effectiveness.

abstract: TPG Growth, low-profile fund led by William McGlashan Jr, will announce that it has raised $3 billion in private equity capital, significant move away from what TPG was initially known for--leveraged buyouts of companies.
headline: At TPG, a Low-Profile Fund’s Diversity Thrives

abstract: Indonesia is expected to move forward with execution of nine people, mostly foreigners, convicted of drug crimes, despite protests and diplomatic tensions; mass execution will be largest of its kind in decades, and comes amid campaign by Pres Joko Widodo to combat what he calls 'national emergency' of drug abuse.
headline: Despite Protests, Indonesia Moves Forward to Execute Drug Convicts
paragraph: Nine people, most of them foreigners, are scheduled to go before firing squads in what is believed to be the largest mass execution in the nation in decades.
text: Despite Protests, Indonesia Moves Forward to Execute Drug Convicts Nine people, most of them foreigners, are scheduled to go before firing squads in what is believed to be the largest mass execution in the nation in decades. Indonesia is expected to move forward with execution of nine people, mostly foreigners, convicted of drug crimes, despite protests and diplomatic tensions; mass execution will be largest of its kind in decades, and comes amid campaign by Pres Joko Widodo to combat what he calls 'national emergency' of drug abuse.

abstract: Unskilled and semiskilled Chinese workers are struggling to find better employment in country's inefficient job market; many have sought new work amid urbanization and decline in agriculture jobs, but overstressed manufacturing sector and soaring university enrollment have resulted in lopsided supply and demand; issue presents critical test for nation's policy makers as they seek to maintain economic growth.
headline: China’s Economy Puts New Pressure on Its Lopsided Job Market
paragraph: With its uneven pockets of supply and demand and decline in agriculture jobs, China’s huge manufacturing sector is showing new signs of stress.
text: China’s Economy Puts New Pressure on Its Lopsided Job Market With its uneven pockets of supply and demand and decline in agriculture jobs, China’s huge manufacturing sector is showing new signs of stress. Unskilled and semiskilled Chinese workers are struggling to find better employment in country's inefficient job market; many have sought new work amid urbanization and decline in agriculture jobs, but overstressed manufacturing sector and soaring university enrollment have resulted in lopsided supply and demand; issue presents critical test for nation's policy makers as they seek to maintain economic growth.

abstract: Justice Dept under Atty Gen Eric H Holder has sided with police officers in every Supreme Court case involving accusations of excessive force, drawing criticisms from some who say police abuses could best be stemmed at federal rather than local level; every federal decision in favor of officers makes it more difficult for citizens to seek justice for claims of mistreatment.
headline: At Supreme Court, Eric Holder’s Justice Dept. Routinely Backs Officers’ Use of Force
paragraph: At the Supreme Court, the attorney general’s office consistently backs officers accused of abuse, even as it pursues civil rights investigations against several local police departments.
text: At Supreme Court, Eric Holder’s Justice Dept. Routinely Backs Officers’ Use of Force At the Supreme Court, the attorney general’s office consistently backs officers accused of abuse, even as it pursues civil rights investigations against several local police departments. abstract: European foreign ministers meet in Luxembourg to consider how to respond after estimates that as many as 900 migrants might have died off Libyan coast; crisis has prompted calls to reconsider approach to surge of refugees from Middle East and Africa; European leaders must grapple with growing anti-immigrant sentiment and balance humanitarian responsibilities with budget constraints.
headline: Rising Toll on Migrants Leaves Europe in Crisis; 900 May Be Dead at Sea
paragraph: The European Union met in Luxembourg on Monday to discuss the disasters as rescuers scrambled to find survivors after ships sank Saturday and early Sunday.

headline: Hundreds of Families Trapped by Fighting in Yemen's Aden
paragraph: Hundreds of families are trapped in their homes by weeks of fierce fighting in the center of the southern city of Aden, running short of supplies — their only lifeline coming from volunteers making dangerous runs across the city's harbor in rickety boats bearing food and medicine.
text: Hundreds of Families Trapped by Fighting in Yemen's Aden Hundreds of families are trapped in their homes by weeks of fierce fighting in the center of the southern city of Aden, running short of supplies — their only lifeline coming from volunteers making dangerous runs across the city's harbor in rickety boats bearing food and medicine.

abstract: Private-public partnership led by developer Wexford Science and Technology is creating 145-acre technology business park on site of former cigarette manufacturing plant outside Winston-Salem, North Carolina; Wake Forest Innovation Quarter will focus on needs of 21st-century technology companies, creating facilities for data analysis, biotech health research and medical education.

abstract: Michael Botticelli is first person in substance-abuse recovery program to hold position of director of White House Office of National Drug Control Policy, or drug czar; Botticelli's appointment points to lessening stigma around addiction and beginnings of shift from punitive approach to drug abuse to one based on healing.

abstract: Op-Ed article by science researcher Mark Lynas describes his conversion from staunch opponent of genetically modified foods to supporter; holds benefits of GMO foods, like eradicating need for pesticide use, allows farmers like those in Bangladesh growing genetically modified eggplants to rise out of poverty and feed their starving families; says if not for such anti-GMO sentiments worldwide, more third-world countries could gain from genetic engineering.
headline: How I Got Converted to G.M.O. Food
paragraph: We can’t deny the science: Biotech works — for good.

abstract: Advocates for same-sex marriage and their lawyers have prepared for months for oral arguments at Supreme Court in hopes of convincing justices to issue broad ruling on constitutionality of same-sex marriage; court has allotted time for debate on questions of whether states are required to allow such marriages and whether states are required to recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere.
headline: Lawyers Seek Sea Change on Gay Rights at Supreme Court
paragraph: Those arguing against states’ bans on same-sex marriage hope the justices will reach a bold verdict that would transform the status of gay Americans.

abstract: Opening arguments begin in Aurora, Colo, movie theater shooting trial; prosecutors argue that James E Holmes deserves death penalty, and defense lawyers claim he was legally insane when he sprayed bullets into packed theater in 2012, killing 12 people and wounding 70 others.

abstract: Millions of Nepalese are living outdoors in wake of massive earthquake, struggling to cope with heavy rain, food shortages, disease and intense aftershocks that continue to convulse area around Katmandu; residents are focused on immediate survival as authorities and rescue workers begin to discover extent of death and destruction; international relief effort has begun, but logistics of getting aid to those in need remain daunting.
headline: Earthquake Aftershocks Jolt Nepal as Death Toll Rises Above 3,400
paragraph: Residents were on a difficult search for safety in Katmandu, where thousands have died and homes and temples have been reduced to rubble.
text: Earthquake Aftershocks Jolt Nepal as Death Toll Rises Above 3,400 Residents were on a difficult search for safety in Katmandu, where thousands have died and homes and temples have been reduced to rubble. abstract: Wisconsin jury finds former sheriff's deputy Andrew Steele not legally responsible in shooting deaths of his wife and sister-in-law because he has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease; defense claimed he developed dementia from condition and was not guilty due to mental illness; some clinicians worry case may stigmatize ALS patients as being violent.
headline: Doctors Worry Verdict in A.L.S. Murder Case Could Stigmatize the Disease

abstract: Demas Fikadey, Israeli soldier of Ethiopian descent, becomes symbol of rage and frustration felt by many young Ethiopian-Israelis after video of him being beaten by police officers is shown on national television and spread on social media; video has sparked violent protests and inspired others to come forward with their own stories of police discrimination and harassment.
headline: Soldier Becomes Unlikely Face of Ethiopian-Israeli Discontent
paragraph: Demas Fikadey, 21, does not see himself as a symbol, but has emerged as one since his beating by police officers set off an outburst of anger.

headline: US Vets Come to Vietnam to Confront Past, and Find a Home

abstract: Destruction and suffering wrought by powerful earthquake in Nepal have been exacerbated by nation's endemic political and economic problems; survivors cite nation's tolerance of poor construction and development norms, its shoddy infrastructure and other factors that made it far more vulnerable to quake; natural disaster, compounding dire economic situation, has led to atmosphere of despair.
headline: In an Already Troubled Nepal, a Picture of Despair Emerges
paragraph: Nepal was in political and economic disarray well before a powerful earthquake on Saturday shattered buildings, and lives.
text: In an Already Troubled Nepal, a Picture of Despair Emerges Nepal was in political and economic disarray well before a powerful earthquake on Saturday shattered buildings, and lives. Destruction and suffering wrought by powerful earthquake in Nepal have been exacerbated by nation's endemic political and economic problems; survivors cite nation's tolerance of poor construction and development norms, its shoddy infrastructure and other factors that made it far more vulnerable to quake; natural disaster, compounding dire economic situation, has led to atmosphere of despair.

abstract: Writer and director Alex Garland discusses his new film Ex Machina, which entails robots and artificial intelligence.
headline: Alex Garland of ‘Ex Machina’ Talks About Artificial Intelligence
paragraph: The writer and director is optimistic about technology and the future.
text: Alex Garland of ‘Ex Machina’ Talks About Artificial Intelligence The writer and director is optimistic about technology and the future. Writer and director Alex Garland discusses his new film Ex Machina, which entails robots and artificial intelligence.

headline: 'Tiger Man' Fights for Return of Seized Animals to Sanctuary
paragraph: The maze of steel cages where bears and black leopards roamed for more than three decades are quiet now. The growls and roars of tigers and lions no longer echo across Kenny Hetrick's backyard and into his neighbor's windows.
text: 'Tiger Man' Fights for Return of Seized Animals to Sanctuary The maze of steel cages where bears and black leopards roamed for more than three decades are quiet now. The growls and roars of tigers and lions no longer echo across Kenny Hetrick's backyard and into his neighbor's windows.

abstract: The Appraisal column; Mamaroneck Beach & Yacht Club's plan to add seasonal apartments in effort to revive club membership has created numerous disputes and lawsuits over property rights, development and preservation; opponents fear that other clubs or boat yards will follow suit, and no maritime users will be left.

headline: Exclusive-World Bank's Pension Investments Clash With Principles
paragraph: The World Bank indirectly invests part of its $18.8 billion (12 billion pounds) staff pension fund in companies in industries such as coal and tobacco, holdings that clash with the development institution's own calls for ethical and low-carbon investing.

abstract: Republican Sen Bob Corker of Tennessee single-handedly stops progress of House-Senate agreement that would deliver balanced budget, despite bipartisan clamor for more spending; refuses to sign agreement, citing what he calls a 'budget gimmick' that would allow for $190 billion in extra spending over 10-year period; Republican leaders call dispute temporary and express hopes for imminent final vote.
headline: Corker Stops Progress of Budget Deal, Even as Pressure for More Spending Builds
paragraph: Before its official unveiling, the budget agreement is already threatened with irrelevance amid a bipartisan clamor for more spending in a new era of loosening belts.
text: Corker Stops Progress of Budget Deal, Even as Pressure for More Spending Builds Before its official unveiling, the budget agreement is already threatened with irrelevance amid a bipartisan clamor for more spending in a new era of loosening belts. Republican Sen Bob Corker of Tennessee single-handedly stops progress of House-Senate agreement that would deliver balanced budget, despite bipartisan clamor for more spending; refuses to sign agreement, citing what he calls a 'budget gimmick' that would allow for $190 billion in extra spending over 10-year period; Republican leaders call dispute temporary and express hopes for imminent final vote.

headline: New Airstrikes in Yemen After Saudis Say Operation Over
paragraph: Hours after Saudi Arabia declared an end to its coalition's nearly monthlong air campaign in Yemen, new airstrikes Wednesday hit Iran-backed militants and their allies in two cities, and the rebels said they would welcome U.N.-led peace talks in the conflict that has killed more than 900 people.
text: New Airstrikes in Yemen After Saudis Say Operation Over Hours after Saudi Arabia declared an end to its coalition's nearly monthlong air campaign in Yemen, new airstrikes Wednesday hit Iran-backed militants and their allies in two cities, and the rebels said they would welcome U.N.-led peace talks in the conflict that has killed more than 900 people.

abstract: New residency requirements have only increased controversy surrounding Malta's citizenship program, which offers passport to those willing to pay 1.2 million euros, or $1.3 million; rules require applicants to rent property in country for 12 months, but not to actually reside there; critics say nation is selling citizenship only to global elite, creating haven with tax advantages and freedom to travel throughout the European Union.
headline: Malta Offers Citizenship and All Its Perks for a Price

headline: Insight-Two Migrant Sisters From Syria, Now Worlds Apart
paragraph: In a small town south of Beirut, Fawziyeh keeps her apartment immaculately clean despite its crumbling walls and the plastic sheets flapping across its windows. She shares the three-bedroom flat with 12 others including her five children – all, like her, refugees from Syria.

abstract: Software program offered through company BiologicTx allows people in need of kidney transplants and willing donors to form kidney-transplant chains where organs are swapped around to create best donor-recipient matches; sale of kidneys is banned in United States, but joining conventional donor wait list can result in years of delays before safe match is found; donor chains, founded on altruism, represent what economists call matching market.
headline: The Great American Kidney Swap
paragraph: Waiting for a donated organ is a long shot, and buying one is illegal. But sophisticated software, combined with old-fashioned selflessness, could be a solution.
text: The Great American Kidney Swap Waiting for a donated organ is a long shot, and buying one is illegal. But sophisticated software, combined with old-fashioned selflessness, could be a solution. Software program offered through company BiologicTx allows people in need of kidney transplants and willing donors to form kidney-transplant chains where organs are swapped around to create best donor-recipient matches; sale of kidneys is banned in United States, but joining conventional donor wait list can result in years of delays before safe match is found; donor chains, founded on altruism, represent what economists call matching market.

abstract: News Analysis; King Salman of Saudi Arabia rearranges order of royal succession, placing security and counterterrorism experts Prince Mohammed bin Nayef and Prince Mohammed bin Salman next in line; move, prompted by concerns over Iran's nuclear program and infirmity of original top princes, carries potential to reshape kingdom and its relations with United States; new leaders have shown little interest in democratic reforms.

abstract: Ana Charle, director of Project Renewal Shelter in Bronx, is abducted and killed by West Spruill, former shelter resident with history of mental illness and violent behavior; Spruill had forced Charle to undress in her car and then opened fire as she fled naked down street; has been charged with second-degree murder and criminal possession of weapon; it is not yet known whether Charle was raped.
headline: Former Resident Kills Director of Bronx Homeless Shelter, Police Say
paragraph: The suspect, West Spruill, forced Ana Charle, 36, to undress in her car, chased her as she tried to flee and then shot her in the street, officials said.
text: Former Resident Kills Director of Bronx Homeless Shelter, Police Say The suspect, West Spruill, forced Ana Charle, 36, to undress in her car, chased her as she tried to flee and then shot her in the street, officials said. Ana Charle, director of Project Renewal Shelter in Bronx, is abducted and killed by West Spruill, former shelter resident with history of mental illness and violent behavior; Spruill had forced Charle to undress in her car and then opened fire as she fled naked down street; has been charged with second-degree murder and criminal possession of weapon; it is not yet known whether Charle was raped.

abstract: New York Public Library, Brooklyn Public Library and Queens Library request $1.4 billion in addition to $566.1 million already included in city's 10-year capital plan for previously approved library projects; hope to use money to bring all 217 branches up to modern building standards.
headline: New York Public Libraries Warn of a ‘Staggering’ Crisis With Infrastructure
paragraph: The libraries seek $1.4 billion from the city for renovations because a number of branches with badly aging buildings have been unable to meet the growing needs of their patrons.

abstract: Postwar graduates of women's liberal arts college Sweet Briar, reacting to news that school will shut down in August 2015, reflect upon way that it shaped them and their careers; some alumnae have started campaign to save school, and have so far raised $1 million in funds with another $10 million pledged.
headline: The Independent Women of Sweet Briar
paragraph: In the days before coeducation at the college level became widespread, Sweet Briar, the small liberal arts women’s college set to close later this year, was more than just a finishing school for Southern women before they became wives.

abstract: The Upshot; new study set for publication by Equality of Opportunity Project suggests that geographic location has enormous impact on upward mobility for poor people; data upends grim findings of Moving to Opportunity anti-poverty study 20 years earlier, which seemed to show that poor families did not benefit after being moved to better neighborhoods; report comes amid climate of deep unrest concerning inequality.

abstract: Case filed by Jim Obergefell challenging Ohio's ban on same-sex marriage, which will go before Supreme Court, illustrates how far Cincinnati has come from its traditionally conservative roots; while city, where Obergefell and his now deceased partner John Arthur lived, is technically the defendant, its attorneys have refused to defend Ohio ban, and city's leaders frequently market it as friendly to homosexuals, bisexuals and transgender people.

headline: Special Report: British Voters Heading for a Disunited Kingdom
paragraph: Like millions of other British voters, Karl Wakeman supported Margaret Thatcher’s Conservatives in the 1980s and then Tony Blair’s New Labour in the late 1990s. But now, as Britain heads toward a general election on May 7, the 49-year-old from Gloucester has no time for either of the two parties that have dominated British politics for decades.

abstract: Profile of Jonathan M Nelson, billionaire media mogul who is aiming to resurrect fortunes of his Providence Equity Partners, firm that lost hundreds of millions of dollars on risky bets and dangerously fast growth in lead-up to financial crisis; Nelson's acknowledgment of his past mistakes marks rare humility in high-powered world of private equity.
headline: The Private Equity Firm That Grew Too Fast
paragraph: Flush with cash, Providence Equity Partners made a series of risky, and disastrous, bets during the private equity boom. Now its chief executive is aiming for redemption.
text: The Private Equity Firm That Grew Too Fast Flush with cash, Providence Equity Partners made a series of risky, and disastrous, bets during the private equity boom. Now its chief executive is aiming for redemption. Profile of Jonathan M Nelson, billionaire media mogul who is aiming to resurrect fortunes of his Providence Equity Partners, firm that lost hundreds of millions of dollars on risky bets and dangerously fast growth in lead-up to financial crisis; Nelson's acknowledgment of his past mistakes marks rare humility in high-powered world of private equity.

headline: Special Report: How Denmark's Unexpected Killer Slipped Through the Net
paragraph: On Valentine's Day, two weeks after his release from prison, Omar Abdel Hamid El-Hussein walked up to a Copenhagen cafe hosting a debate on freedom of speech and sprayed it with bullets.
text: Special Report: How Denmark's Unexpected Killer Slipped Through the Net On Valentine's Day, two weeks after his release from prison, Omar Abdel Hamid El-Hussein walked up to a Copenhagen cafe hosting a debate on freedom of speech and sprayed it with bullets.

abstract: Canadian founders of Uranium One, major producer of nuclear material that would eventually be sold to Russia's state-owned Rosatom, made millions of dollars in donations to Clinton Foundation as deal was pending; donations came during Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State, and coincided with her department's approval of sale; examination of deal and its security implications has raised serious questions about conflict of interests as Clinton pursues presidential bid.
headline: Cash Flowed to Clinton Foundation Amid Russian Uranium Deal
paragraph: As the Russian atomic energy agency gradually took charge of a company that controls one-fifth of all uranium production capacity in the United States, a stream of cash made its way to the former president’s charitable organization.
text: Cash Flowed to Clinton Foundation Amid Russian Uranium Deal As the Russian atomic energy agency gradually took charge of a company that controls one-fifth of all uranium production capacity in the United States, a stream of cash made its way to the former president’s charitable organization. Canadian founders of Uranium One, major producer of nuclear material that would eventually be sold to Russia's state-owned Rosatom, made millions of dollars in donations to Clinton Foundation as deal was pending; donations came during Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State, and coincided with her department's approval of sale; examination of deal and its security implications has raised serious questions about conflict of interests as Clinton pursues presidential bid.
